Synthesis of Compound {[Co2L2MA]⋅(DMA)(MeOH)}n (1)

A mixture of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (45 mg, 0.15 mmol) 0.33 mmol melamine (MA, 0.04 g), 0.50 mmol 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (H2L, 0.08 g), 3 mL DMA and 2 mL MeOH were mixed uniformly and added in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was heated to 100 °C with a rate of 5 °C/min and kept at 100 °C for 72 h. After being cooled to 20 °C with a rate of 5 °C/min, pink block crystals were obtained. Then crystals were washed with MeOH and dried in the air. Yield: ca. 44% (based on H2L). Anal. Calcd (%) for compound 1 (C20H23Co2N7O10S2): C, 34.45; H, 3.49; N, 13.92%. Calculate: C, 34.15; H, 3.30; N, 13.94%.

cln_elements.content:
A new three-dimensional transition Co(II)–organic framework {[Co2L2MA]·(DMA)(MeOH)}n (MA = melamine, H2L = 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid) bearing the rigid S-containing organic ligand 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid and the N-rich organic linker melamine has been synthesized and structurally characterized. The presence of abundant micropores in the resulting activated 1a has been confirmed via the N2 sorption experiments at 77 K, which reflects a BET surface area of 925 m2/g and a pore size distribution of 7.4 Å. Furthermore, the catalytic activities of complex 1 for the degradation of methyl orange in a Fenton-like process have also investigated, which reveals that complex 1 could behave as effective as heterogeneous catalyst to activate persulfate anions and to degrade methyl orange. To evaluate the inhibitory effect of compound 1 on H9C2 myocardioma cells, the viability of cells after compound treatment was detected by CCK-8 assay, and the proliferation of cells were observed by colony formation assay. Next, the detail mechanism of compound 1 was further explored, the western blot was performed to determine the relative expression of apoptotic protein Blc-2 and Bax.

Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) themselves are a relatively new and rapidly growing class of compounds. These inorganic–organic porous materials are microporous crystals comprised of metal ions linked by organic bridging ligands, which possess unique attributes, such as tailorable molecular properties, good thermal stability and uniform structured nano scale cavities [9]. These features endow them with outstanding properties and potential applications in drug delivery, gas storage, separation, molecular sensing, adsorption, and especially in catalysis [10–12]. Very recently, researchers have investigated the use of iron-based metal organic frameworks as persulfate catalysts and have made some progress [13–15]. In this study, a new three-dimensional (3D) transition Co(II)–organic framework (MOF) {[Co2L2MA]·(DMA)(MeOH)}n (MA = melamine, H2L = 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid) bearing the rigid S-containing organic ligand 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid and the N-rich organic linker melamine has been synthesized and were structurally characterized. The presence of abundant micropores has been confirmed via the N2 sorption experiments at 77 K, which reflects a BET surface area of 1012 m2/g and a pore size distribution of 6.7 Å. Furthermore, the catalytic activities of complex 1 for the degradation of methyl orange in a Fenton-like process have also investigated, which reveals that complex 1 could behave as effective as heterogeneous catalyst to activate persulfate anions and to degrade methyl orange. To evaluate the anti-cancer activity of compound 1 on H9C2 myocardioma cells, the CCK-8 and the cell colony formation assay was conducted. All the results indicate the excellent inhibitory effect of compound on cancer cells. Besides, we also confirmed the compound 1 could induce the apoptosis of cancer cells by changing the expression of Bcl-2 and Bax.

PXRD, Thermogravimetric and BET Analysis for Complex 1

To confirm that the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, PXRD experiments were carried out for the bulky as-prepared 1 in different synthesis runs at room temperature. The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the corresponding compounds in the Fig. 2a show that they are the same regarding to the peak positions, indicating the as-prepared complex 1 is in high phase purity. The slightly different intensity for the peaks in the different positions should be attributed to the crystal face preferred orientation effects. Considering the following catalytic reaction, the water stability of complex 1 was checked by soaking the freshly prepared 1 in water for 1 day and then the corresponding PXRD pattern was collected. As shown in the Fig. 2a, the peak positions of the samples of complex 1 in water showed a good match with that of freshly prepared complex 1 with a slightly difference in the peak intensity, which indicates the complex 1 kept its framework integrality after being soaked in water for 1 day. The slightly difference in the peak intensity might be due to the different lattice solvents. According to the literature, the lattice solvents could also contribute to the diffraction intensities in the PXRD patterns [20]. At the same time, to investigate the thermal stability of 1, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiment was carried out in the temperature range 25–800  C under a flow of nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 (Fig. 2b). The TGA curve for the complex 1 showed the weight loss of 16.7% in the temperature range 25–210  C, corresponding to the loss of one lattice DMA and one MeOH molecule (calcd: 16.3%), after which there is no obvious loss until about 370 °C. During the temperature range of 380–550  C, a sharp weight loss of 65.1% was occurred. The weight loss was calculated to the decomposition of the organic ligands, suggesting the framework of 1 was totally collapsed. In order to remove the lattice DMA solvents in 1, the as-prepared samples of 1 was soaked in the MeOH for 3 days and then activated at 393 K for 12 h. The absence of the lattice solvents in 1a (the solvent-free 1) has been confirmed via the TGA analysis, which reflects that no obvious weight loss could be observed in the temperature of 25 to 350  C. Furthermore, the framework robustness in the activation process gas been confirmed via the PXRD measurements, which indicates its good framework stability in the above mentioned treatments. Porosity and surface area of 1a were confirmed by N2 adsorption analysis at 77 K. As illustrated in Fig. 2c, the complex 1a exhibited type I adsorption isotherm behavior, evidencing its microporous feature. The hysteresis phenomenon may be caused by hindered diffusion through the narrow pore apertures. The BET surface area for 1a was 925 m2/g, indicating the existence of microporous in the framework of 1a. The pore size distribution of 1a was calculated based on desorption isotherm using nonlocal DFT (density functional theory) and its pore size mainly centers around 7.4 Å (Fig. 2d).

Herein, we tested complex 1 as heterogeneous catalystes to activate persulfate anions and to degrade methyl orange in the aqueous solution. The photodegradation activity results of complex 1 are compared with the activity of control blank (i.e. non-catalytic). The progress of the catalysis degradation of methyl orange reaction was estimated by monitoring the absorbance characteristic of methyl orange at 506 nm. As shown in Fig. 3, the degradation efficiency was 92.6% for 1 after 150 min. In contrast to the control experiments (without MOF samples and with the metal salts and organic ligands), which are 15.2%, 11.3% and 5.7%, respectively. To make a further comparison, the Zn(II)-MOF which is structurally isostructural to the complex 1 was also studied. The degradation efficiency of Zn(II)-MOF is lower than Co(II)-MOF, which may be due to their different metal centers. Compared to the Zn(II)-MOF, the Co(II)-MOF 1 performs better at the beginning, the residual rate of methyl orange was decreased to 12% in the first 50 min. Subsequently, the reaction continued slowly and nearly ceased at the end. The activity of complex 1 in the degradation of methyl orange may be due to S2O82−, it can be transformed into sulfate radicals (SO4·−) by catalysis of 1 whilst Co2+ was oxidized into Co3+. The Zn(II) ion is difficult to oxidize or reduce due to its stable d10 configuration so it showed a much lower catalysis activity. In addition, the complex 1 kept its framework integrality after the catalytic reaction which has been validated from the PXRD measurement (Fig. 2a).

Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully prepared a new three-dimensional (3D) transition Co(II)–organic framework by using the rigid S-containing organic ligand 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid and the N-rich organic linker melamine as co-linkers. The single crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Cmcm and displays a 3D framework with channels of dimensions 10.06 Å × 10.12 Å running along the [1 0 0] direction. The presence of abundant micropores has been confirmed via the N2 sorption experiments at 77 K, which reflects a BET surface area of 1012 m2/g and a pore size distribution of 6.7 Å. Furthermore, the catalytic activities of complex 1 for the degradation of methyl orange in a Fenton-like process have also investigated, which reveals that complex 1 could behave as effective as heterogeneous catalyst to activate persulfate anions and to degrade methyl orange. We observed that the newly synthesized compound could significantly inhibit the viability and proliferation of H9C2 myocardioma cells in vitro, which is proved by CCK-8 assay and cell colony formation assay. In addition to this, we also proved that the apoptosis was induced in cancer cells after compound treatment. The relative expression of Bcl-2 was significantly decreased, while Bax increased. Above all, we draw this conclusion, the compound could induce apoptosis and inhibit cancer cell progression in vitro.
